questions.questionText: Which sentence demonstrates correct parallel structure?

choices.label: A
choices.text: She enjoys reading, to swim, and hiking on weekends.

choices.label: B
choices.text: She enjoys reading, swimming, and hiking on weekends.

choices.label: C
choices.text: She enjoys to read, swimming, and to hike on weekends.

choices.label: D
choices.text: She enjoys reading, to be swimming, and hikes on weekends.

questions.explanation: Parallel structure requires items in a list to follow the same grammatical pattern. Answer B uses three gerunds (reading, swimming, hiking). The other options mix gerunds, infinitives, and conjugated verbs.

questions.questionText: Which sentence uses the semicolon correctly?

choices.label: A
choices.text: The experiment failed; because the temperature was too high.

choices.label: B
choices.text: The experiment failed; the temperature was too high.

choices.label: C
choices.text: The experiment; failed the temperature was too high.

choices.label: D
choices.text: The experiment failed, the; temperature was too high.

questions.explanation: A semicolon joins two independent clauses that are closely related. 'The experiment failed' and 'the temperature was too high' are both complete sentences. Answer A is wrong because 'because' makes the second part a dependent clause, which should not follow a semicolon.

questions.questionText: Which sentence contains a dangling modifier?

choices.label: A
choices.text: Walking through the park, the birds sang beautifully in the trees.

choices.label: B
choices.text: Walking through the park, Maria heard the birds singing beautifully.

choices.label: C
choices.text: Maria walked through the park and heard the birds singing.

choices.label: D
choices.text: As Maria walked through the park, the birds sang beautifully.

questions.explanation: In sentence A, 'Walking through the park' is a participial phrase that should modify the subject that follows. But the subject is 'the birds,' implying the birds were walking through the park. This is a dangling modifier. Sentence B correctly makes 'Maria' the subject.

questions.questionText: Which revision most effectively combines these two sentences? "The committee proposed a new policy. The policy was controversial among faculty members."

choices.label: A
choices.text: The committee proposed a new policy, it was controversial among faculty members.

choices.label: B
choices.text: The committee proposed a new policy and controversial among faculty members.

choices.label: C
choices.text: The committee proposed a new policy that proved controversial among faculty members.

choices.label: D
choices.text: The committee proposed a new policy, being controversial among faculty members.

questions.explanation: Answer C uses a relative clause ('that proved controversial') to smoothly combine the sentences. Answer A is a comma splice. Answer B is grammatically incomplete. Answer D creates a dangling modifier that suggests the committee, not the policy, is controversial.

questions.questionText: Which sentence correctly uses the subjunctive mood?

choices.label: A
choices.text: If I was the president, I would change the law.

choices.label: B
choices.text: If I were the president, I would change the law.

choices.label: C
choices.text: If I am the president, I would change the law.

choices.label: D
choices.text: If I be the president, I would change the law.

questions.explanation: The subjunctive mood is used for hypothetical or contrary-to-fact conditions. 'If I were' (not 'was') is the correct subjunctive form because the speaker is not actually the president. This applies regardless of the subject being singular.

questions.questionText: Which sentence uses the colon correctly?

choices.label: A
choices.text: The three branches of government are: legislative, executive, and judicial.

choices.label: B
choices.text: The three branches of government include: legislative, executive, and judicial.

choices.label: C
choices.text: There are three branches of government: legislative, executive, and judicial.

choices.label: D
choices.text: The government has: three branches that are legislative, executive, and judicial.

questions.explanation: A colon should follow an independent clause (a complete sentence). 'There are three branches of government' is a complete thought. In answers A, B, and D, the colon interrupts the natural flow between a verb and its object — 'are,' 'include,' and 'has' all need their complements without a colon.

questions.questionText: Which sentence has an ambiguous pronoun reference?

choices.label: A
choices.text: When Sarah met Elena, she was nervous about the interview.

choices.label: B
choices.text: Sarah was nervous about the interview when she met Elena.

choices.label: C
choices.text: Sarah, who was nervous about the interview, met Elena in the lobby.

choices.label: D
choices.text: Nervous about the interview, Sarah met Elena in the lobby.

questions.explanation: In sentence A, 'she' could refer to either Sarah or Elena — the reader cannot determine who was nervous. Sentences B, C, and D all make it clear that Sarah is the one who is nervous through sentence structure and clause placement.

questions.questionText: Which sentence maintains parallel structure in a complex list with correlative conjunctions?

choices.label: A
choices.text: The proposal was not only rejected by the board but also the shareholders voted against it.

choices.label: B
choices.text: Not only was the proposal rejected by the board, but also the shareholders voted against it.

choices.label: C
choices.text: The proposal was not only rejected by the board but also opposed by the shareholders.

choices.label: D
choices.text: Not only the board rejected the proposal but also the shareholders opposing it.

questions.explanation: Correlative conjunctions ('not only...but also') require parallel grammatical structures on each side. In answer C, both sides follow the same pattern: 'rejected by the board' / 'opposed by the shareholders' (past participle + by + agent). The other options break this symmetry.
